title: Michelangelo’s cheese and Lucian Freud’s nose: the secrets of artists’ letters
text:
I got the twelve cheeses. They are excellent,” Michelangelo writes to thank his nephew Lionardo in December 1550. The gay septuagenarian artist then gives his young heir a few gruff tips on how to choose a wife. Day-to-day, family stuff. But Michelangelo’s handwriting tells another story, covering the page in the beautifully legible script developed by Renaissance thinkers to share their ideas.

During Michelangelo’s lifetime, the practice of writing letters, maintaining highly literate, long-distance contact with friends, patrons, fellow professionals, came to express a new sense of what it meant to be an artist – someone who worked with their brain as well as their hands.
